channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: The U.S. is designating Ecuador's largest gangs as terrorists
item.description: The U.S. is designating Ecuador's two largest gangs — Los Choneros and Los Lobos — as foreign terrorist organizations.
item.content:encoded:
The U.S. is designating Ecuador's two largest gangs — Los Choneros and Los Lobos — as foreign terrorist organizations.

(Image credit: Jacquelyn Martin)
item.dc:creator: Michele Kelemen

item.title: For mixed status families, deportation fears cast shadow over new academic year
item.description: As the new school year begins, mixed immigration status families face heightened fears about ICE enforcement near schools, creating anxiety that extends far beyond the classroom.
item.content:encoded:
As the new school year begins, mixed immigration status families face heightened fears about ICE enforcement near schools, creating anxiety that extends far beyond the classroom.

(Image credit: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds/AFP)
item.dc:creator: Jasmine Garsd

item.title: Experiencing pain? Sanjay Gupta explains why 'It Doesn't Have to Hurt'
item.description: Gupta's new book examines the world of pain — why we feel it, and how we can treat it. He says distraction and meditation can be useful tools for managing certain kinds of pain.
item.content:encoded: Gupta's new book examines the world of pain — why we feel it, and how we can treat it. He says distraction and meditation can be useful tools for managing certain kinds of pain.
item.dc:creator: Terry Gross

item.title: Senators from both parties grilled RFK Jr. on vaccines and more
item.description: In a blistering hearing, Senators from both parties challenged the health secretary to defend his actions, including on vaccines access and CDC leadership.
item.content:encoded:
In a blistering hearing, Senators from both parties challenged the health secretary to defend his actions, including on vaccines access and CDC leadership.

(Image credit: Andrew Harnik)
item.dc:creator: Yuki Noguchi

item.title: Why the medical community is thrilled by U.S. support for a 'breakthrough' HIV drug
item.description: Lenacapavir has the potential to end the HIV epidemic, researchers say. The Trump administration says backing this kind of effort will be a model for how it does global health work in the future.
item.content:encoded:
Lenacapavir has the potential to end the HIV epidemic, researchers say. The Trump administration says backing this kind of effort will be a model for how it does global health work in the future.

(Image credit: Nardus Engelbrecht)
item.dc:creator: Gabrielle Emanuel

item.title: Senators grill Trump's nominee for Fed amid alarms over central bank independence
item.description: White House economist Stephen Miran was quizzed by senators about whether he could make decisions independently of President Trump, if he's confirmed to a seat on the Federal Reserve's governing board.
item.content:encoded:
White House economist Stephen Miran was quizzed by senators about whether he could make decisions independently of President Trump, if he's confirmed to a seat on the Federal Reserve's governing board.

(Image credit: Win McNamee)
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: A clash of the comebacks: Osaka and Anisimova face off in the U.S. Open semifinals
item.description: Naomi Osaka and Amanda Anisimova will face off in the U.S. Open semifinals on Thursday. Both players have been climbing up the rankings after taking mental health breaks from the sport.
item.content:encoded: Naomi Osaka and Amanda Anisimova will face off in the U.S. Open semifinals on Thursday. Both players have been climbing up the rankings after taking mental health breaks from the sport.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: Denying famine, Israel threatens more curbs on Gaza aid
item.description: Despite experts saying that famine has begun in Gaza, Israel is threatening more curbs on aid deliveries. Aid groups say extra restrictions will make the starvation crisis worse.
item.content:encoded:
Despite experts saying that famine has begun in Gaza, Israel is threatening more curbs on aid deliveries. Aid groups say extra restrictions will make the starvation crisis worse.

(Image credit: Eyad Baba/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf

item.title: The NFL is back. Here are 3 big questions as the season kicks off
item.description: Which second-year quarterbacks will take a leap forward? Does the Micah Parsons trade make Green Bay a contender? And will Buffalo or Baltimore finally keep the Kansas City Chiefs from the Super Bowl?
item.content:encoded:
Which second-year quarterbacks will take a leap forward? Does the Micah Parsons trade make Green Bay a contender? And will Buffalo or Baltimore finally keep the Kansas City Chiefs from the Super Bowl?

(Image credit: Patrick Smith)
item.dc:creator: Becky Sullivan

item.title: Fashion designer Giorgio Armani, whose name became synonymous with luxury, dies at 91
item.description: Armani's clothes highlight the body as an object of art. Celebrities have flaunted his fashion on red carpets for decades. He revolutionized the suit jacket, with casual silhouettes and softer colors.
item.content:encoded:
Armani's clothes highlight the body as an object of art. Celebrities have flaunted his fashion on red carpets for decades. He revolutionized the suit jacket, with casual silhouettes and softer colors.

(Image credit: Pascal Le Segretain)
item.dc:creator: Diana Opong
